item.title: Pokemon GO: How To Get Shiny Rookidee
item.description:
Rookidee was the "starter" Flying-type Pokemon you'd find at the beginning of Pokemon Sword & Shield . Although Rookidee and its evolutions have been a part of Pokemon GO since January 2025's "Steeled Resolve" event, Shiny Rookidee/Corvisquire/Corviknight did not debut the same day. With the "Ultra Unlock: Steel and Scales" event (July 2025), Shiny Rookidee has officially been released into the wild. From July 22, 2025, at 10:00 a.m. to July 27, 2025, at 8:00 p.m. local, there will be an increase spawn of Rookidee in Pokemon GO . During this event, you should try and catch yourself a Shiny Rookidee or two.

Where to Find Shiny Rookidee

Ultra Unlock: Steel and Scales, July 2025

During "Ultra Unlock: Steel and Scales" (July 22-27, 2025), you'll see an increase of the following Pokemon in the wild:

  • Rookidee
  • Bagon
  • Beldum
  • Dratini
  • Magnemite
  • Aron
  • Ferroseed
  • Noibat
  • *Axew
  • *Goomy

* Axew and Goomy appear to be rarer encounters, but you'll still see more of them than you would on average.

Rookidee being a Flying-type means it's more likely to spawn during windy weather, but during "Ultra Unlock", you should be seeing Rookidee regardless of weather conditions. Keep in mind that Rookidee is not a 1-star Raid Pokemon during the event.

If you're trying for Shiny Rookidee, you'll have better luck walking around than staying in one spot and waiting for it to appear. To increase the chances of Rookidee spawning, you can use a Lure Module on a nearby PokeStop, or you can use Incense. Moss, Glacial, Magnet, and Rainy Lure Modules won't attract Flying-type Rookidee, so just use the regular, purple module.

You may also want to turn on AR Mode while Shiny Hunting. This gets rid of the load time for the "Catch/Encounter Screen," making it quicker to see the Pokemon.

If you miss out on Shiny Rookidee during the "Ultra Unlock" event, don't worry. Shiny Rookidee is officially in Pokemon GO , so you'll still be able to catch it. However, Rookidee's spawn rate outside the event is determined by other factors, such as weather. Meaning it may be harder to come by a Shiny Rookidee normally than it would during "Ultra Unlock: Steel and Scales."

Should You Evolve Shiny Rookidee?

How to Get Shiny Corvisquire and Shiny Corviknight

To evolve Shiny Rookidee into Shiny Corvisquire, you'll need 25 Rookidee Candy . To evolve your Shiny Corvisquire into Shiny Corviknight, you'll need 100 Rookidee Candy . You'll want to catch a lot of Rookidee to farm Candy for its two evolutions. "Ultra Unlock: Steel and Scales" doesn't have an increased Candy amount, but you can use Pinap or Silver Pinap Berries to increase the Candy drop from Rookidee.

You can and should evolve Shiny Rookidee to register Shiny Corvisquire and Shiny Corviknight to unlock their (Shiny) Pokedex entries. However, if you plan to use Shiny Corviknight competitively, against Team GO Rocket, or to defend gyms, you may want to evolve a 3-star (or 2-star with high Defense) instead of a 0/1-star. Getting a 3-star Shiny all comes down to luck, but it is possible.

Here are some recommended Fast Attacks and Charged Attacks:

Move Name

item.title: ‎Grow a Garden: Complete Zen Event Guide
item.description:
The Grow a Garden devs keep rolling out weekly events to keep the Roblox experience fresh, and this time they’ve introduced the Zen event; a Chinese-themed update focused on leveling up the event shop and buying new items.

But it’s not as simple as it sounds. Just like the Bee Swarm event, you’ll need to collect a brand-new currency called Chi, which is earned by giving fruits with the Tranquil variant. The event runs for eight days, from July 19 to July 26 . Here's a full look at what’s included and how to take part in Grow a Garden's Zen event.

Trade Chi & Buy from Zen Shop

Firstly, there’s a Chi trader at the event shop, a raccoon and panda-like creature who’s ready to channel Chi for you if you hand over Tranquil Plants. Since Chi is the currency needed to buy items from the Zen Shop (also called Tranquil Treasures), you’ll need to earn it before grabbing anything you like.

Mainly, you can get Tranquil Plants when the Zen event starts. It happens every hour and lasts for 10 minutes. When the event is active, a shiny glow appears and turns your crops into Tranquil. Some of these variants give more Chi than others, so it's better to grow the right ones. If you're not sure which ones to use, we’ve made this simple guide to help you pick the best Tranquil Plants for farming Chi.

Grow Zen Channeller Tree

Next, you’ve got the Zen Channeller, a Monk NPC on a platform to the right of the Chi Trader. He takes your Tranquil Plants and gives you Zen in return (which works just like Chi). That Zen gets added to an upgrade bar. With each level, the tree behind him grows, and new items become available in the Zen Shop. It’s the same system as Chi, so you’ll snag the same amount of Zen as the Chi value of the plants you give.

Each time you do an upgrade, you’ll get random rewards like Zen Seed Pack, Zen Crate, Zen Egg, and more. You can also restock the Zen Shop using Sheckles, but keep in mind, the restock cost goes up each time, so spend wisely.

item.title: Rumor: Zenless Zone Zero Is Bringing Over a Popular Genshin Impact Mini-Game
item.description:
A new leak from Zenless Zone Zero is suggesting that a fan-favorite mini-game from Genshin Impact may soon be making the jump to the HoYoverse urban action RPG. HoYoverse's newest RPG has been a smash hit throughout the year since its release, quickly amassing tens of millions of players and making the jump to Xbox with the Version 2.0 update. The developer has added plenty of new game modes to Zenless Zone Zero since its release, including Deadly Assault and a new management mini-game with the Suibian Temple. Now, Zenless Zone Zero may have an exciting mini-game coming soon.

Since it first debuted during Genshin Impact 's Version 1.4, the beloved RPG's rhythm mini-game quickly became a staple of new Genshin Impact events. Players could jam along to some of their favorite songs from Genshin Impact and earn a copy of the instrument used for the event as a reward. Genshin Impact would even make its rhythm mini-game a permanent fixture during the Version 5.3 update. Zenless Zone Zero may now be following suit with a rhythm game of its own.

Zenless Zone Zero Leak Hints at New Mini-Game

A recent leak shared by prominent HoYoverse leaker Mero suggests that Zenless Zone Zero will soon be adding its own rhythm mini-game. The leaked video features a lineup of some of Zenless Zone Zero 's most popular songs, including Burnice's "Burning Desires" and Astra Yao's "Original Me" among others. The post does not share any details about how the rhythm game will play, though it is expected to function similarly to Genshin Impact 's rhythm mini-game. Zenless Zone Zero 's rhythm mini-game is expected to launch as part of the Version 2.2 update, scheduled to release on August 27.

The addition of a rhythm mini-game to Zenless Zone Zero comes as the game's music has often been a viral part of its marketing. The music video for the previously-mentioned Burning Desires went viral following its debut, still standing as one of the most viewed videos on Zenless Zone Zero 's official YouTube channel. Astra Yao's "Original Me" is also featured prominently within Zenless Zone Zero , with the song playing in-game after Astra Yao uses her Ultimate.

The recent launch of Zenless Zone Zero 's Version 2.1 similarly saw some exciting content brought to the RPG. Version 2.1 welcomed two new characters to the game's roster, with Yuzuha and Alice joining as the first members of the new "Spook Shack" faction. The update also debuted the newest chapter of the game's main story, alongside summer-themed skins for Belle and Wise and both of the update's new characters. Zenless Zone Zero looks to keep the Waifei Peninsula's early momentum rolling with a fun-filled summer update for fans to enjoy.

item.title: Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds Reveals Nostalgic Freebie for Sega Fans
item.description:
Sega is giving away a Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds version of the Blue Star from Sonic Riders . This nostalgic freebie became available just two months ahead of Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds ' multi-platform release.

First announced at the December 2024 edition of The Game Awards, CrossWorlds is the next big racing game from Sega, as well as a direct follow-up to the massively successful Team Sonic Racing , which sold 3.5 million copies between its mid-2019 release and June 2025. It is scheduled to hit the market on September 25.

In the run-up to this release, Sega unveiled a new freebie in the form of the Blue Star, an Extreme Gear from the classic 2006 arcade racer Sonic Riders . Sonic's hoverboard—designed by Tails in the original game's lore—is being given away to anyone who signs up for a Sega Account. The only other requirement is linking at least one platform to the account. The key here is for fans to link their profiles to a platform on which they plan to play Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds .

How To Claim Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds Blue Star

  1. Sign up for a Sega Account
  2. Link the account with at least one platform on which Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds will be available
  3. Buy Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds
  4. Claim the Blue Star promo code via the Free Gift Promotion website between September 25 and October 31
  5. Redeem the promo code on the platform/storefront for which it was issued

The Blue Star offer may not be available in all regions.

In a social media post announcing the promotion, Sega said that the offer is only available in select regions, albeit without elaborating on the matter. Social media reports from fans suggest that the promo is at the very least available in North America and Europe. Existing Sega Account owners who have already linked at least one gaming platform to their profile are automatically eligible for the freebie and will receive their complimentary Blue Star once Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds releases on September 25.

The Blue Star will be distributed via promo codes for the game's target platforms. Sonic fans will only be able to claim one promo code for a single platform of their choice, even if they end up buying the game on multiple storefronts. The window for grabbing a code runs between the game's September 25 release until October 31, at 10:59am ET / 16:59: CET. Buying the arcade racer during this period is a prerequisite for claiming a Blue Star code.

The Blue Star offer continues Sega's ongoing efforts to incentivize Sega Account sign-ups, following similar promotions in Shinobi: Art of Vengeance and Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii , as well as Raidou Remastered: The Mystery of the Soulless Army . The Blue Star will ostensibly be far from the only connection between Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds and Sonic Riders , as Sega's recent teasers suggest the former will heavily reference the latter.

item.title: 6 Best Open-World Games That Play Like A Tabletop RPG, Ranked
item.description:
Some open-world games throw in stat points and call it a day. Others go further. They give players worlds that feel reactive, characters who act like they have their own character sheets, and enough freedom to rewrite the rulebook mid-campaign.

These games capture the spirit of a tabletop RPG, where choice matters, risk is real, and systems are designed to encourage curiosity over power fantasies. From dicey persuasion checks to brutal encumbrance systems and factions that actually care about what players did ten hours ago, this list spotlights the open-world games that come closest to scratching that D20-shaped itch.

6 Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen

Dragons Don’t Level Scale And Neither Does Consequence

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen
6.6 /10
Released
April 23, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Partial Nudity, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
Capcom
Platform(s)
Xbox One, Xbox 360, PC, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4
Powered by

Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen feels like it was designed by someone who heard D&D players asking “Can I do this?” and decided to say yes to everything. It doesn’t explain much, and that’s what gives it tabletop energy. Players start as the Arisen, a customizable blank slate who gets their heart ripped out by a dragon and embarks on a journey that’s more about exploration and personal growth than story exposition. Nighttime is legitimately dangerous, pawns speak like party members with bad improv instincts, and combat has a weight to it that demands respect.

One of the most “roll a nat 1” things that can happen is wandering into an area too early and getting squashed by a griffin, because the game doesn’t care what level anyone is. Add in systems like carrying unconscious allies manually, dynamic monster encounters based on time and weather, and emergent weirdness like stacking pawns to reach a ledge, and it starts to feel like a homebrew campaign spiraling out of the DM’s control in the best way possible.

5 Gothic 2: Night of the Raven

The Townsfolk Remember That Goblin You Killed Two Chapters Ago

Gothic 2
6.0 /10
Released
October 28, 2003

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
Piranha Bytes
Platform(s)
PC
Powered by

No one forgets their first hour in Gothic 2: Night of the Raven , because it feels like the entire world is actively trying to kill or humiliate the player. Every NPC has a schedule, every faction has its own tangled politics, and every attempt to sneak into a place too early ends with a beatdown and a scolding. What gives it such a strong tabletop feel is the way reputation works. Players aren’t just ticking off quest boxes. They’re building an actual reputation with named NPCs who won’t trust them unless they’ve heard of them doing something useful.

The expansion, Night of the Raven , not only adds content, but overhauls the entire balance of the game. Choosing between factions like the fire mages, mercenaries, or paladins doesn’t just impact combat; it changes how the story is told and how the world responds. The game punishes impatience but rewards creativity. Overhearing the right conversation or figuring out an alternate route into a camp can mean the difference between success and a painful reminder that not every problem can be solved with violence.

4 Outward

Every Step Forward Feels Like A Tactical Retreat

Outward
RPG
Systems
Released
March 26, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Partial Nudity, Violence
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

Outward isn’t about being the chosen one. It’s about surviving the fallout of a bad deal, a cursed bloodline, or just a really awful backpack. From the very start, players are put on the back foot. There’s debt to pay, cold weather to endure, and bandits who will rob everything, including clothes, and leave them unconscious in a cave. The world is open, but it doesn’t feel built to empower. It feels like a space where planning, preparedness, and knowing when to run are more valuable than any stat boost.

There are no autosaves. Magic requires unlocking the skill by sacrificing maximum health. Combat is stamina-based and punishing, and most fights feel like mini tactical puzzles. Players can place traps before ambushes, mix potions with limited resources, and rely heavily on their gear and travel supplies.

It’s a game that rewards methodical play, like a GM who makes survival a core theme of the campaign. The result is an open world that isn’t only about exploration, but about forging a believable personal story of hardship, adaptation, and small victories that matter far more than world-ending threats.

3 Mount & Blade 2: Bannerlord

A Sandbox Where Everyone’s Playing Their Own Campaign

Mount & Blade 2: Bannerlord
8.0 /10
Released
October 25, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood, Violence
Developer(s)
TaleWorlds Entertainment
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

No one hands out quests in Mount & Blade 2: Bannerlord unless players are ready to forge their own story through diplomacy, trade, and an unhealthy number of decapitations. It drops players into Calradia as a nobody with a sword, and lets them decide whether they’ll rise through economics, become a feared mercenary captain, or betray every lord and carve out a kingdom of their own.

In typical tabletop fashion, choices aren’t presented as branching dialogue options. Instead, they emerge naturally from the systems. Marrying into a noble family, sieging castles, or selling off prisoners like livestock all happen because someone saw an opportunity and ran with it.

What makes it sing as a tabletop experience is how open-ended everything is. Party composition, gear, faction alignment, vassal politics, the economy — these are mechanics, but they also feel like hooks in a campaign that adapts to the story players are telling. One playthrough might be focused on building a merchant empire; the next might be a revenge-driven arc fueled by watching a sibling get captured during a failed raid. The game doesn’t care which path is taken. It keeps simulating a world full of moving parts and asking one question: what’s the next move?

2 Kingdom Come: Deliverance

Honor, Horses, And A Long List Of Bruises

Kingdom Come: Deliverance
10
7.6 /10
Released
February 13, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Alcohol
Developer(s)
Warhorse Studios
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC, Switch
Powered by

What Kingdom Come: Deliverance lacks in dragons and magic, it makes up for in brutal historical accuracy. Set in 1403 Bohemia, it doesn’t follow a legendary hero. It follows Henry, a blacksmith’s son who can barely swing a sword, read, or ride a horse without flopping off. And that’s exactly what makes it feel like a slow-burning tabletop campaign. Skills improve only with use, conversations can fail due to poor speechcraft, and failing a quest might mean it’s permanently gone.

Every system feels designed to reflect immersion first. Armor layering affects mobility and protection. NPCs respond to whether Henry is covered in blood or dressed like nobility, and injuries need to be treated manually. There’s even a hardcore mode that removes the HUD and auto-saves, turning the game into a medieval survival simulator.

It’s not about being overpowered, it’s about living through the story one clumsy swordfight and awkward political favor at a time. Like a good GM, the game punishes recklessness but rewards genuine roleplay, curiosity, and a little bit of book-learning.

1 Fallout: New Vegas

Failing A Speech Check Might Start A War

Fallout: New Vegas
8 /10
22
8.9 /10
Released
October 19, 2010

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Drugs
Developer(s)
Obsidian Entertainment
Platform(s)
PS3, Xbox 360, PC
Powered by

Of all the open-world games that channel the spirit of a tabletop RPG, Fallout: New Vegas is the closest to feeling like a DM is sitting behind the screen. Built on the old-school Fallout DNA and helmed by many of the original developers from Fallout 2 , it’s a narrative sandbox where stats actually matter, and where the player’s build impacts how quests play out. A high speech skill can talk entire factions out of violence. A low intelligence stat rewrites the protagonist’s dialogue into near-gibberish.

Every faction has layers. The NCR aren't ’just the “good guys”; they’re a bureaucratic machine with stretched resources. Caesar’s Legion is horrifying, but ideologically coherent. And the Yes Man route? It’s basically an anarchist’s dream of flipping the table and starting fresh.

Players who roleplay specific builds — like a pacifist, a stealthy chem addict, or a dumb-as-rocks melee bruiser — get completely different story outcomes. Combine that with multiple endings, reactive quests, mod support, and a fanbase that still analyses its moral dilemmas like a college philosophy course, and it’s no wonder New Vegas still holds the crown. It’s a living, irradiated campaign where the dice are always rolling in the background.

More
The Best RPG Of All Time

The RPG genre is one of the largest in existence, with games from all over the world; there are countless games that fall into this genre. Considering it is so large, it can be difficult to decide which is the best one ever. We have seen games like Skyrim, World of Warcraft, Fallout 4, Hades, Diablo, Elden Ring, The Witcher 3, Chrono Trigger, Final Fantasy 7, and so many more games that have blown fans expectations out of the water. I think that when trying to decide which game is the best, we need to consider the core elements of the genre. The major points of RPGs are that your character has to develop based on your decisions, your character's experiences in combat and conversation should be affected by your attributes, and your character exists in a fleshed-out world that has a deep storyline. Looking at this, I think that the best RPG is Baldur's Gate 3. I think that Larian Studios nailed it when it comes to creating a world that you affect, they thought of everything that players
